body:
LGTM

In the future, we should consider using multiple Dockerfiles, so that customizations like picking a different version of tensorflow is easier. But, for now, a single container image is fine.

There are a couple of TODOs remaining. Here are some notes from tonight:
- rebased to master and squashed
- WordCount works, reading from and writing to S3
- need to do some bigger testing
- haven't looked at coverage yet
- Kinesis tests fail for me both before and after this PR, so I made a fix and we'll see what Jenkins does with it. If that doesn't work, AWS SDK version 1.11.24 is the last version that should pass without any change in Beam.
- there are two open questions to @jkff , mentioned inline
- tried to do more tonight, but fixing the content encoding bug turned out to be more complex than I anticipated.
@amitsela fair enough, let me create a new PR replacing this one.
Updated the PR, hope it addresses the comments.
@aljoscha It should be ok now, please take a look.
Tests failed for timeout in Spark ValidatesRunner, just created #4194 to address this.
This LGTM and you can also move the timer cleanup code. ðŸ‘
Addressed remarks, waiting for CI to be happy before merge, thanks !
run java precommit
@kennknowles thanks for taking care of it. Unfortunately the pre-commit builds were unavailable to catch it.
R: @malo-denielou
retest this please
R: @tvalentyn
Looks like some precommit tests are failing.
It is now, although the other option is just listing a different version of setuptools as required in our setup file.
Fixed. PTAL.
retest this please
@robertwb sometimes
Odd. Well, this can't hurt. LGTM.
LGTM. Thanks a lot Robert!

I think it will be cleaner to require min setuptools version, that does not cause this issue.

@tvalentyn do you know what would be the minimum version of setuptools for this?

@aaltay I don't know the very minimal version for which it will work. Are there concerns with setting 36.7.2?

Also do we really need to parse version here to get the container name as opposed to using `container_version=pkg_resources.get_distribution(GOOGLE_PACKAGE_NAME).version`?

In the past we had seen issues with other dependencies that required particular versions of setuptools, or higher version of setuptools. It manifiests as installation problems, with incompatible setuptools requirements. It also creates issues if a user has a lower version and mid-installation setuptools is upgraded.

> Also do we really need to parse version here to get the container name as opposed to using container_version=pkg_resources.get_distribution(GOOGLE_PACKAGE_NAME).version?

I believe this is correct. If you can verify this, this would be a better and simpler solution.
Hi @aaltay , Can you please take a look?

> I believe this is correct. If you can verify this, this would be a better and simpler solution.

I can take a look - feel free to reassign me the JIRA tracking this problem.

run java gradle precommit

Backing channel disconnect

@reuvenlax Thanks for your comment. Where can I read up on the other attempt? I've also created a feature request at issuetracker.google.com to hopefully allow BigQuery to support schema updates on streaming inserts "natively".

Updated according the comments.
Run Flink ValidatesRunner
Thanks @aljoscha !
@amitsela  Please take a look it should be ok now, and the tests pass but jenkins is a bit crazy.

Hi @charlesccychen. Here are some fixups addressing your review comments.
Should I merge with latest from apache/beam master, or will you?

Even with these changes, it takes several seconds to process even modest sized files (e.g. a few MB). Profiling suggests much of it is due to the creation of many Timestamp objects. Is the team aware of / planning to address this? Thanks.
jenkins: retest this please

Thank you!  Can you rebase to the head of master?

I am currently working on a rearchitecture of the DirectRunner to improve scalability, especially for multi-core environments (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1442).  This should be ready for use in the next few months.
LGTM

We are aware of the slow performance of the Direct runner, and hope to address it more directly. 

In the meantime, you could also try running with `pipeline(runner=apache_beam.runners.portability.fn_api_runner.FnApiRunner())` which can help on some pipelines.
Test failures are not related. Great to see it green already.

I've rebased, thought not sure I've done it correctly. It looks OK in GitHub Desktop:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/692834/33506536-4444bb88-d6be-11e7-9994-b3c17ddc64f3.png)

Thanks for the info re performance.

After the merge, running it fails due to missing `beam_runner_api_pb2`:
```
$ time python wordcount_minimal.py --input kinglear_x4.txt --output counts
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "wordcount_minimal.py", line 53, in <module>
    import apache_beam as beam
  File "/Users/nedgar/Development/Apache-Beam/apache_beam/__init__.py", line 86, in <module>
    from apache_beam import coders
  File "/Users/nedgar/Development/Apache-Beam/apache_beam/coders/__init__.py", line 18, in <module>
    from apache_beam.coders.coders import *
  File "/Users/nedgar/Development/Apache-Beam/apache_beam/coders/coders.py", line 30, in <module>
    from apache_beam.portability.api import beam_runner_api_pb2
ImportError: cannot import name beam_runner_api_pb2
```

@c0b I will close this PR based on (https://beam.apache.org/contribute/contribution-guide/#stale-pull-requests). Please file JIRA issues for the issues you found.

If you are interested in writing an SDK, some recommended reads would be:
https://s.apache.org/beam-fn-api
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/CONTAINERS.md

Beam is working on a new effort (portability) to make it easier to introduce SDKs and above has related pointers to that.
PTAL.

Looks good. Jenkins is complaining. 

Jenkins: retest this please.

R: @kennknowles @reuvenlax @iemejia 
Please take a look
retest this please

Thomas, if this does not fix the falkiness of the test, maybe we can start to accept empty source splits. Either:
- remove the assert: but it seems weak to me because even if we ensure that there is the expected number of splits, and a regression in `source.split()` that leads to only one non empty split would not be caught and would reduce the parallelism for sure.
- set a number of acceptable empty splits and assert(empty splits <= this number). But what is the acceptable number ?
Findbugs seems to fail on core runner.
R: @jkff can you please take a look? thanks

TextIO is failing on dataflow runner. Bug is described and currently investigated in separate dataflow related issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/BEAM/issues/BEAM-3268 here is a fix for our tests. cc @chamikaramj
I fixed findbugs issue.
retest this please
This PR is superseded by #4208
R: @kennknowles (for the merge into go-sdk)
R: @tgroh
R: @herohde
Run Java PostCommit
WindowedValue & friends are actually only in the construction side SDK for legacy reasons, and a smidge for testing and reification convenience.
Fixed test failure, PTAL.

Expanding a bit - the elements and windows each have a specified encoding, each element is in exactly one window, but how the runner does the bookkeeping about which window an element is in is deliberately unspecified.
Note that the Java implementation still sends a list of Windows and not a singular value since that is how FullWindowedValueCoder currently works.
Run Spark ValidatesRunner
Run Python PreCommit

Yes. single-firing bounded global window is the other one that I was hoping
we could attack soon as well. This is why I opted to add window coders here
rather than remove then from the worker side. (That and changing all the
workers is a much taller ordeal...)

On Mon, Dec 4, 2017 at 2:42 PM, Kenn Knowles <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@kennknowles* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In runners/core-construction-java/src/main/java/org/apache/
> beam/runners/core/construction/PCollectionTranslation.java
> <https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4211#discussion_r154797988>:
>
> > @@ -33,7 +34,10 @@ private PCollectionTranslation() {}
>
>    public static RunnerApi.PCollection toProto(PCollection<?> pCollection, SdkComponents components)
>        throws IOException {
> -    String coderId = components.registerCoder(pCollection.getCoder());
> +    String coderId = components.registerCoder(
>
> My personal preference would be to tie it to the data plane, or I guess
> control plane since the data plane is just the byte stream. In some ways,
> PCollection is a misnomer for the intermediate nodes of a
> ProcessBundleDescriptor. On the other hand, having a single graph structure
> is nice.
>
> And I am not at all against this special representation on the wire - I
> agree it is a huge win. I just want to leave the door open to more wins.
> Like single-firing bounded global window computation, where we can omit all
> the metadata. I think each of them will need to be standardized so SDKs can
> implement them, and the runner chooses from a menu of options. Going into
> fancier negotiation protocols seems excessive for this particular case
> since there's probably a single-digit number of Coder<WindowedValue> that
> are interesting. OTOH a pretty interesting case is going columnar so
> there's no WindowedValue to speak of at all.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4211#discussion_r154797988>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAdqgbCjTN6MRZ40ZXM4yosvGhsglotFks5s9HVtgaJpZM4Q1Plm>
> .
>
If maven is happy, I'm happy. This is a nice feature.
Test failure seems like an infrastructure flake.
R: @wcn3 @lostluck

Jenkins failure: ERROR: beam8 is offline

Jenkins: retest this please
LGTM (but I'm not a committer)
R: @wcn3 @lostluck
Good point. Let me try to add a test, especially in "pure" streaming mode.

TBH not sure how this worked before, especially since your change is subtractive. I probably am missing something, but here's my $0.02:

The class is part of `com.google.protobuf:protobuf-util-java` which is a dependency of `runners-core-construction-java` where the reference is made, but the shading of the direct runner relocates `com.google.protobuf.**` without bundling that artifact. It bundles the core protobuf artifact, which will not contain everything that is needed. So my reading is that the config is just wrong.

Editorial: I used to be annoyed that it was hard to distribute `x.y` separately from `x.y.z` in Python but that practice in java is a positive nightmare. The most fun part is where `x.y.q` might be in the same jar and `x.y.z` is in a separate jar.
Ping! WDYT about rebasing and resolving the conflicts? This definitely seems useful.

LGTM

Previously, there was a licensing reason for the XML file to be used. Now that reason is resolved. Since this PR is open still, can you just port the line in the XML to be a more localized `@SuppressFBWarning`? Or if there's another solution go for it, but just commenting here to push this through and finish it off.

I am for doing it, but have not found the time. I'm happy to close this in the intermediate time

Empty splits are allowed to be returned since many times you can't tell if there is data for a key range without performing an expensive operation. If you can tell whether the split is empty or not quickly its worthwhile to filter out ranges without any data but I don't think its wise to test that all splits contain data and instead bound to like 50% of splits contain data.
R: @wcn3 @lostluck
Alternatively R: @tgroh
I'll wait for tests. It would be snazzy to exercise this in a test but I see how that is a pain. And anyhow it has to be in first, due to our Jenkins set up.
PTAL?
